Nest, Horida, to Navana, Cuba, January 16, 1928
Fokker F-T

Mistoric First Flights of Pan American Clippers
Pan American's first passenger flight
Key Nest, Florida, to Mavana,
fanuary 16, 1928
Seven passengers board a Pan American Fokker F-7 (NC53), inaugurating scheduled United States-flag
commercial passenger service between Key West and Havana, a distance of 90 miles. The trimotor, high-wing
monoplane was commanded by Captain Hugh I. Wells. A sister ship flown by Captain Edwin C. Musick took off a
few minutes earlier, carrying mail and cargo to Havana.
This passenger flight was one of Pan American's many aviation 'firsts.' It was preceded by the inauguration
of airmail service to Havana on October 28, 1927, Pan Am's first flight and the first scheduled international flight
by an American airline.
About the Artist
In 1926, John T. McCoy became a working student for the Curtiss Flying Ser-
vice, Curtiss Field, Long Island, New York.
When Charles A. Lindbergh arrived at Curtiss Field, his SPIRIT OF ST. LOUIS
was housed in one of the Curtiss hangars. It was at this time that McCoy met
Lindbergh, who was most cordial and friendly to those who worked on the flight
line. In those days muscle power was the method used for starting engines, ac-
complished by swinging the propeller by hand. McCoy often pulled a prop through
Years later, when McCoy was commissioned to do paintings depicting the
history of Pan American World Airways, Inc. - entitled HISTORIC FIRST FLIGHTS
OF PAN AMERICAN CLIPPERS - he consulted with Lindbergh on the selection of
aircraft and locations for the series.
This is one picture in a series of thirteen. If you would like to purchase 8½" x 11"
or 16" x 20" limited edition prints, send your letter of inquiry to: Public Relations
Department - Pan American World Airways, Inc., Pan Am Building, New York, New
York 10166. Please include code number 304 in your letter.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Menu issued by Pan American World Airways; reproduction of watercolor of Fokker F.VII with caption, "Pan American's first passenger flight Key West, Florida, to Havana, Cuba, January 16, 1928"; includes information about historic flight and artist; menu items include beef, lamb, and sole; menu number: 247K; class: Clipper (business); date: 11-1-82.
properties.sfomuseum:series: Historic First Flights Series; cover illustrations by John T. McCoy
